Description: New facts in science are derived from testing hypotheses and REPRODUCIBLY showing results that prove or disprove the hypothesis.  A key issue for generating reproducibility is properly choosing the tools.  Antibodies are amongst the most challenging tools in the toolbox.  While some vendors are extremely diligent in validation, others are not and thus antibody selection is a major source of non-reproducibility.  Similarly, even great antibodies used at suboptimal concentrations can give non-reproducible results. Finally, the user should think about the use case and select their antibody reagents with that in mind.  This session will focus on antibody use in spatially informed visualization of targets (immuno-histochemistry and immunofluorescence).  We will discuss considerations for antibody selection and usage in the context of High-plex discovery, low-plex quantitative applications, and finally introduce trainees to the considerations for use of antibodies in the clinical setting, including CAP/CLIA context validation.
SearchResultBody: MW14. Choosing and Using Antibodies for Spatial Informed Protein Expression
Title: Choosing and Using Antibodies for Spatial Informed Protein Expression
